segment.source: Windows RE troubleshooting features
segment.target: Windows RE troubleshooting features

segment.source: Windows RE troubleshooting features
segment.target: Windows RE troubleshooting features

segment.source: Windows RE troubleshooting features
segment.target: Windows RE troubleshooting features

segment.source: If a Windows device can't start, it automatically fails over to the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE).
segment.target: If a Windows device can't start, it automatically fails over to the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE).

segment.source: The Automatic Repair tool in Windows RE automates the diagnosis and repair of an unbootable Windows installation.
segment.target: The Automatic Repair tool in Windows RE automates the diagnosis and repair of an unbootable Windows installation.

segment.source: Windows RE is also a starting point for several tools for manual system recovery.
segment.target: Windows RE is also a starting point for several tools for manual system recovery.

segment.source: This topic describes the automatic failover behavior, manual diagnosis, and repair process in Windows RE.
segment.target: This topic describes the automatic failover behavior, manual diagnosis, and repair process in Windows RE.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Recovering from Startup Failures
segment.target: Recovering from Startup Failures

segment.source: Advanced Troubleshooting Utilities in Windows RE
segment.target: Advanced Troubleshooting Utilities in Windows RE

segment.source: Recovering from startup failures
segment.target: Recovering from startup failures

segment.source: If the system detects a boot failure on a computer running Windows, the system automatically fails over into the on-disk Windows RE tool.
segment.target: If the system detects a boot failure on a computer running Windows, the system automatically fails over into the on-disk Windows RE tool.

segment.source: At startup, the Windows loader sets a status flag to indicate that the boot process has started.
segment.target: At startup, the Windows loader sets a status flag to indicate that the boot process has started.

segment.source: Windows typically clears this flag before the Windows logon screen appears.
segment.target: Windows typically clears this flag before the Windows logon screen appears.

segment.source: However, if the boot attempt fails, Windows doesn't clear the flag.
segment.target: However, if the boot attempt fails, Windows doesn't clear the flag.

segment.source: The next time that the computer starts, the loader detects the flag and assumes that a boot failure occurred.
segment.target: The next time that the computer starts, the loader detects the flag and assumes that a boot failure occurred.

segment.source: When this occurs, the loader starts Windows RE instead of Windows.
segment.target: When this occurs, the loader starts Windows RE instead of Windows.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Boot failure detection relies on boot completion and not whether an error occurred in Windows 8.
segment.target: Boot failure detection relies on boot completion and not whether an error occurred in Windows 8.

segment.source: For example, a false positive may occur if power is lost during the boot process, and your user starts Windows RE even though the Windows installation is bootable.
segment.target: For example, a false positive may occur if power is lost during the boot process, and your user starts Windows RE even though the Windows installation is bootable.

segment.source: Because the failover mechanism relies on the Windows boot manager and the Windows boot loader, some failures can make Windows RE inaccessible.
segment.target: Because the failover mechanism relies on the Windows boot manager and the Windows boot loader, some failures can make Windows RE inaccessible.

segment.source: In the following scenarios, your user must use the bootable Windows RE media to recover the computer:
segment.target: In the following scenarios, your user must use the bootable Windows RE media to recover the computer:

segment.source: Corrupt disk metadata exists in the master boot record (MBR), partition table, or boot sector of a Windows RE partition.
segment.target: Corrupt disk metadata exists in the master boot record (MBR), partition table, or boot sector of a Windows RE partition.

segment.source: The boot manager is missing or corrupted.
segment.target: The boot manager is missing or corrupted.

segment.source: The Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store is missing or corrupted.
segment.target: The Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store is missing or corrupted.

segment.source: If the boot loader can't read or write to the boot status flag, Windows won't be able to automatically fail over into Windows RE.
segment.target: If the boot loader can't read or write to the boot status flag, Windows won't be able to automatically fail over into Windows RE.

segment.source: However, your user can still manually start the on-disk Windows RE tool through the Boot Options menu.
segment.target: However, your user can still manually start the on-disk Windows RE tool through the Boot Options menu.

segment.source: Advanced troubleshooting utilities in Windows RE
segment.target: Advanced troubleshooting utilities in Windows RE

segment.source: Your user can manually start several system recovery tools after starting the on-disk Windows RE tool from the recovery media, or from the Boot Options menu.
segment.target: Your user can manually start several system recovery tools after starting the on-disk Windows RE tool from the recovery media, or from the Boot Options menu.

segment.source: With the exception of Automatic Repair, the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) doesn't include these tools.
segment.target: With the exception of Automatic Repair, the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) doesn't include these tools.

segment.source: Push-button reset is the recommended recovery solution in Windows.
segment.target: Push-button reset is the recommended recovery solution in Windows.

segment.source: Automatic Repair
segment.target: Automatic Repair

segment.source: The Automatic Repair tool automates common diagnostic and repair tasks for non-bootable operating system installations.
segment.target: The Automatic Repair tool automates common diagnostic and repair tasks for non-bootable operating system installations.

segment.source: Automatic Repair starts if the computer fails over into Windows RE because of a detected boot failure.
segment.target: Automatic Repair starts if the computer fails over into Windows RE because of a detected boot failure.

segment.source: If automatic failover to an on-disk instance of Windows RE is not available, your users can also start Automatic Repair as a manual recovery tool from a Windows RE CD or DVD.
segment.target: If automatic failover to an on-disk instance of Windows RE is not available, your users can also start Automatic Repair as a manual recovery tool from a Windows RE CD or DVD.

segment.source: System Image Recovery
segment.target: System Image Recovery

segment.source: Use System Image Recovery for file backup and system image backup.
segment.target: Use System Image Recovery for file backup and system image backup.

segment.source: System Image Recovery requires an external storage device.
segment.target: System Image Recovery requires an external storage device.

segment.source: For file backup, your users can let Windows choose what to back up, or they can select individual folders, libraries, and drives.
segment.target: For file backup, your users can let Windows choose what to back up, or they can select individual folders, libraries, and drives.

segment.source: By default, backups are created on a regular schedule.
segment.target: By default, backups are created on a regular schedule.

segment.source: Your users can change the schedule and manually create a backup at any time.
segment.target: Your users can change the schedule and manually create a backup at any time.

segment.source: After your user sets up System Image Recovery, Windows keeps track of the new or modified files and folders, adding them to the backup.
segment.target: After your user sets up System Image Recovery, Windows keeps track of the new or modified files and folders, adding them to the backup.

segment.source: For system image backup, your users can create a system image or an exact image of a drive.
segment.target: For system image backup, your users can create a system image or an exact image of a drive.

segment.source: A system image includes Windows and system settings, programs, and files.
segment.target: A system image includes Windows and system settings, programs, and files.

segment.source: Your users can use a system image to restore the contents of their computer if the hard disk drive or computer stops working.
segment.target: Your users can use a system image to restore the contents of their computer if the hard disk drive or computer stops working.

segment.source: If your users restore their computer from a system image, the restoration is a complete restoration.
segment.target: If your users restore their computer from a system image, the restoration is a complete restoration.

segment.source: Your users can't choose individual items to restore.
segment.target: Your users can't choose individual items to restore.

segment.source: All of the current programs, system settings, and files are replaced.
segment.target: All of the current programs, system settings, and files are replaced.

segment.source: If you set up a scheduled file backup, you can include a system image with only the drives Windows requires to run.
segment.target: If you set up a scheduled file backup, you can include a system image with only the drives Windows requires to run.

segment.source: You can manually create a system image if you want to include additional data drives.
segment.target: You can manually create a system image if you want to include additional data drives.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Previous system image versions are copies of the files and folders saved automatically by Windows as part of the system protection process.
segment.target: Previous system image versions are copies of the files and folders saved automatically by Windows as part of the system protection process.

segment.source: Depending on the type of file or folder, your users can open a previous version, save the version to a different location, or restore a previous version.
segment.target: Depending on the type of file or folder, your users can open a previous version, save the version to a different location, or restore a previous version.

segment.source: Your users can use these previous versions to restore accidentally modified, deleted, or damaged files or folders.
segment.target: Your users can use these previous versions to restore accidentally modified, deleted, or damaged files or folders.

segment.source: However, because Windows replaces these files with new versions the files won't be available if the drive fails.
segment.target: However, because Windows replaces these files with new versions the files won't be available if the drive fails.

segment.source: Command Prompt
segment.target: Command Prompt

segment.source: All Windows PE command-line tools are available from a command prompt window.
segment.target: All Windows PE command-line tools are available from a command prompt window.

segment.source: For example, you can use Registry Editor (Regedit.exe), which includes command-line switches, to modify the Windows registry.
segment.target: For example, you can use Registry Editor (Regedit.exe), which includes command-line switches, to modify the Windows registry.

segment.source: Or, you can use the Chkdisk.exe tool to troubleshoot and fix volumes.
segment.target: Or, you can use the Chkdisk.exe tool to troubleshoot and fix volumes.

segment.source: For more information, see Registry Editor, Chkdsk, and Troubleshooting Tools and Strategies.
segment.target: For more information, see Registry Editor, Chkdsk, and Troubleshooting Tools and Strategies.

segment.source: Custom Support and Recovery Tools
segment.target: Custom Support and Recovery Tools

segment.source: Computer manufacturers can provide custom support and recovery tools.
segment.target: Computer manufacturers can provide custom support and recovery tools.

segment.source: These tools will vary by manufacturer.
segment.target: These tools will vary by manufacturer.

segment.source: For more information, see the manufacturer-provided documentation.
segment.target: For more information, see the manufacturer-provided documentation.
